content.title: Linear Equations in Two Variables and Function Notation.
Ordered Pair
content.body:
An ordered pair is a pair of real numbers $$a$$, and $$b$$ inside a set of parentheses and separated by a comma, i.e., (a, b). Some examples of ordered pairs are (-3, 2), (4, 7), and (5, 0).
Note:
- The first number in an ordered pair is always called the x - coordinate.
- The second number in an ordered pair is always called the y - coordinate.

content.title: Graphing Paper
content.body: To practice and complete problems for this chapter we will need graphing paper. For free printable graphing paper click on Free Graphing Paper and choose the 'One page with four $$7x7$$ axes only templates', option.

content.title: The Cartesian Coordinate Plane
content.body: To practice and complete problems for this chapter we will need graphing paper. For free printable graphing paper click on Free Graphing Paper and choose the 'One page with four $$7x7$$ axes only templates', option.

content.title: Graphing Ordered Pairs
content.body: To graph an ordered pair (a, b), in the cartesian coordinate plane we first start at the origin and move $$a$$ units to the right if $$a$$ is positive or $$a$$ units to the left if $$a$$ is negative on the x - axis, then move $$b$$ units up if $$b$$ is positive or $$b$$ units down if $$b$$ is negative on the y - axis, then plot a point at the spot where we end up.

content.title: Example
content.example:
Using graph paper, create a coordinate plane as explained earlier in the chapter and graph the ordered pairs.
a) (2,3)

b) (4,3)

c) (-3,5)

d) (-1,-2)

e) (2,0)

f) (0,-5)

content.title: Linear Equation in Two Variables
content.body:
A linear equation in two variables is any equation that can be written in the standard form, $ax+by=c$ where $$a$$, $$b$$ and $$c$$ are real numbers.

Note: Solution to Linear equations in two variables are 'ordered pairs'.

content.title: Example 1
content.example:
Determine if the following ordered pairs are solutions to the equation: $5x-3y=9$ a) $$(0,3)$$
b)$$(3,3)$$
c) $$(6,7)$$

content.title: Finding Solutions to Linear Equation in Two Variables
content.body: To find solutions to linear equations in two variables, we simply choose appropriate values for the x-coordinate, so that it reveals the value of the y-coordinate.

content.title: Finding Solutions to Linear Equation in Two Variables
Example 2
content.example:
Create at least three solutions each for the following linear equations: a) $$4x+7y=7$$
b) $$y=6x+3$$

content.title: Graphing Linear Equations in Two Variables
content.body:
The graphs of a linear equation are straight lines, that's why these equations are called 'linear'. To graph a linear equation we use the following steps
$$\circ$$ Find at least three solutions for the linear equation.
$$\circ$$ Plot the three solutions.
$$\circ$$ Draw a straight line through the three points.

content.title: Graphing Linear Equations in Two Variables
Example 3
content.example:
Graph the following linear equations:

a) $$x=-5$$

b) $$y=4$$

c) $$-3x+9y=9$$
d) $$y=-\dfrac{4x}{5}-1

content.title: $$x$$ and $$y$$ intercepts
content.body:
The y-intercept of a graph of an equation of a line is the point at which the graph crosses the y-axis, likewise the x-intercept of a graph of an equation of a line is the point at which the graph crosses the x-axis.

$$\circ$$ To find the y-intercept of an equation of a line, we set $$x$$ equal to zero and solve for $$y$$.

$$\circ$$ To find the x-intercept of an equation of a line, we set $$y$$ equal to zero and solve for $$x$$.

content.title: Example 4
content.example:
Graph the following linear equations using the $$x$$ and $$y$$ intercepts:

a) $$3x+2y=6$$

b) $$2x-5y=10$$

content.title: Using the Slope and y-Intercept, and the Point Slope Formulas to Find the Equation of a Line
The Slope of a Line
content.body:
The slope of a line is number that measures the steepness of the line when passing through two points, that is,
Given any two points $$(x_{1},y_{1})$$ and $$(x_{2},y_{2})$$ read, 'x sub 1, y sub 1' and 'x sub 2, y sub 2', then the slope of a line $$m$$ passing through two points is given by: $m=\dfrac{y_{2}-y_{1}}{x_{2}-x_{1}}$

content.title: Example 1
content.example:
Find the slope of the line passing through the following paints of points:
a) $$(2,1)$$, $$(5,7)$$

b) $$(4,-2)$$, $$(-5,6)$$

c) $$(-2,-3)$$, $$(-5,-9)$$

content.title: Slope-Intercept Form of the Equation of a Line
content.body: The slope-intercept form of an equation of a line is given by: $y=mx+b$ Where $$m$$ is the slope and $$b$$ is the y-intercept.

content.title: Slope-Intercept Form of the Equation of a Line
Example 2
content.example:
Find the slope and y-intercept for the following linear equations and write in slope y-intercept form:
a) $$10x-5y=30$$
b) $$14x+7y=-3$$
c) y=-\dfrac{1}{5}x+10$$

Find the equation of the line with the given slope and y-intercept and write in slope-intercept form
d) $$m=4$$ and $$b=5$$
e) $$m=\dfrac{11}{3}$$ and $$b=-5$$
f) $$m=-7$$ and $$b=\dfrac{3}{4}$$

content.title: Point-Slope Form of the Equation of a line
content.body: The point-slope form of an equation of a line is given by: $y-y_{1}=m(x-x_{1})$ Where $$m$$ is the slope and $$x_{1}$$ and $$y_{1}$$ are coordinates in an ordered pair $$(x_{1},y_{1})$$

content.title: Point-Slope Form of the Equation of a line
Example 3
content.example:
Find the equation of the line with the given slopes and points:
a) $$m=-4$$, $$(-4,2)$$
b) $$m=\dfrac{2}{3}$$, $$(3,3)$$

Find the equation of the line that passes through the following pairs of points:
c) $$(-4,-7)$$, $$(4,1)$$
d) $$(-2,-6)$$, $$(1,3)$$

content.title: Function
content.body: A function is a rule in which no two ordered pairs share the same x-coordinate. In other words a function is an equation for which any input $$x$$, substituted into the equation will yield one output $$y$$, from the equation.

content.title: Function Notation
content.body:
The output of a function '$$f$$' that corresponds to an input '$$x$$' can be written using function notation and is denoted by $$f(x)$$, (read '$$f$$ of $$x$$'). We use this notation to help identify specific functions and indicate how a function may need to be evaluated.

Note:
$$\circ$$ Any letter of variable can be used in function notation such as, $$g(x)$$, $$f(a)$$, $$s(t)$$.

$$\circ$$ The function notation $$f(x)$$, is not multiplication between $$f$$ and $$x$$.

$$\circ$$ Any linear equation written in slope-intercept form and many non-linear equations written with xy-notation can be written using function notation.

content.title: Example 2
content.example:
Write the following equations using the given function notation:

a) $$y=8x+7$$ as a funtion of $$f$$

a) $$y=8x+7$$ as a funtion of $$f$$

b) $$y=5x^2+2x-11$$ as a funtion of $$g$$

c) $$m=9n-4$$ as a funtion of $$f$$

d) $$r=6T^2-9T+1$$ as a funtion of $$s$$

content.title: Using Function Notation
content.body: To evaluate a function using function notation, say $$f(x)$$, we simply substitute a value for $$x$$ in the function $$f$$ and calculate the value of $$f$$ at $$x$$. This allows us to write more information with fewer symbols and words than we would have used with $$xy$$-notation.

content.title: Example 3
content.example:
Evaluate each function as indicated:

a) $$f(x)=10x-2$$ find $$f(2)$$

b) $$f(x)=5x^2+4x-10$$ find $$f(4)$$

c) $$h(a)=15a+25$$ find $$h(0)$$

a) $$S(x)=2x^2-10x+5$$ find $$S(-5)$$
